But the story actually begins in 1947,

as I learned when getting my PhD in international political economy at Princeton

While postwar planners envisioned a multilateral trade/investment/monetary system after WWII,

the weakness of every industrial economy except the US doomed those efforts to failure

Instead, what developed was a US-centered world political economy w 5 main features

1) The US was, as noted, the only intact industrial power

2) Until 1958, the US dollar was the only currency that was universally accepted,

so it became the global currency for ALMOST ALL international trade & investment

3) The US also had ~50% of world gold reserves

4) Because US-based multinationals dominated global oil trade,

the price of oil was denominated in US dollars

5) Due to its system of military bases throughout the world, 

the US provided security globally outside the Soviet bloc

& became the main engine of international economic growth

The result was the US dollar became the currency for global trade & investment for the rest of the world

This gave the US a privilege no other country had since the Roman Empire:

The ability to construct its fiscal & monetary policies WITHOUT ANY EXTERNAL CONSTRAINTS like trade or balance of payment deficits

Given this, Trump is totally WRONG to claim the US has been "ripped off"

I would like to add that there are specific gains to tariffs, but all will be short lived.

Let's take steel for instance. The price of steel is set by global demand as are most materials. When we levy a 25% tariff on imported steel, the price of domestically produced steel will rise to very near the imported steel price. This is because prices are set by market competition and when the competing price goes up, all other sources go up also.

Now steel is a component part to manufacturing and construction. When the companies that use steel have its cost go up, then they, in turn must raise their prices to their customers. When that happens, their customers buy less product or build less due to higher costs. And then these users of steel buy less steel, regardless of its source. 

So as the effects of higher input costs set in, net economic output drops and everyone losses. This is why there are no winners in a trade war.
